title: God’s Presence and Glory
shortSummary: Exodus 33 reveals the tension between God's holiness and Israel's sinfulness, highlighting the necessity of God's presence for their journey. Moses intercedes for the people, seeking assurance of God's guidance and a revelation of His glory, emphasizing the intimate relationship between God and His chosen leader.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus, during Israel's wilderness journey after leaving Egypt

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who intercedes with God on behalf of the people and seeks a deeper revelation of God's presence and glory.

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ young servant who remains faithfully in the tabernacle during Moses’ encounters with God.

keyCharacters.name: The Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation led by Moses, described as stiffnecked and mourning due to God's warning of judgment and His temporary withdrawal of presence.

definitions.definition: A biblical term describing stubbornness and resistance to God’s will, indicating Israel’s rebellious attitude.
The portable sanctuary set up outside the camp where God met with Moses and the people sought the Lord.
A visible manifestation of God’s presence that guided and protected Israel during their wilderness journey.
The visible manifestation of God’s holiness, power, and presence, which Moses requests to see.

outline.heading: God’s Command and Israel’s Rebellion
outline.description: God instructs Moses to lead Israel to the promised land but declares He will not go with them due to their stubbornness, causing the people to mourn and remove their ornaments as a sign of repentance.

outline.heading: The Tabernacle Outside the Camp
outline.description: Moses sets up the tabernacle outside the camp where God meets him in a cloud, and the people worship from their tents, illustrating the separation caused by sin yet God’s continued communication with Moses.

outline.heading: Moses’ Intercession for God’s Presence
outline.description: Moses pleads for assurance that God will accompany Israel, emphasizing that without God’s presence, their journey and identity as His people are meaningless.

outline.heading: Moses’ Request to See God’s Glory
outline.description: Moses boldly asks to see God’s glory; God reveals His goodness and mercy but explains that no one can see His face and live, showing only His back as a partial revelation of His presence.

application: Trust in God’s presence as essential for guidance and success in life’s journey, just as Israel needed God’s presence to enter the promised land.
Approach God with humility and persistence in prayer, following Moses’ example of intercession for the people and seeking deeper knowledge of God.
Recognize the seriousness of sin and rebellion, which can separate us from God’s presence, and respond with repentance and obedience.
Rejoice in God’s mercy and grace, understanding that His glory is beyond full human comprehension but His goodness is revealed to those who seek Him.

keyVerses.text: And he said, My presence shall go with thee, and I will give thee rest.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures believers that God’s presence brings peace and rest amid trials and uncertainty.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto him, If thy presence go not with me, carry us not up hence.
keyVerses.significance: Moses’ declaration highlights the indispensable nature of God’s presence for the journey of faith and obedience.

keyVerses.text: And he said, Thou canst not see my face: for there shall no man see me, and live.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God’s holiness and the limits of human access to His full glory, emphasizing reverence and awe.

keyVerses.text: And I will take away mine hand, and thou shalt see my back parts: but my face shall not be seen.
keyVerses.significance: God’s partial revelation to Moses teaches that while God reveals Himself, His full essence remains beyond human reach.
